medications.name: Paracetamol (Acetaminophen)
medications.dosageAdult: 500-1000 mg every 4-6 hours as needed (max 4000 mg/day)
medications.dosageChild: Based on weight and age - consult a healthcare provider
medications.safetyNotes: Generally safe for most adults. Avoid if allergic or have liver disease.
medications.warnings: Do not exceed recommended dose. Avoid alcohol. May cause liver damage in high doses.
medications.sideEffects: Generally minimal at correct doses. May include nausea, stomach discomfort.
medications.contraindications: Liver disease, alcoholism, allergic reactions to acetaminophen.

medications.name: Ibuprofen
medications.dosageAdult: 200-400 mg every 4-6 hours as needed (max 1200 mg/day)
medications.dosageChild: Based on weight and age - consult a healthcare provider
medications.safetyNotes: Avoid during pregnancy (especially third trimester). Use lowest effective dose for shortest duration.
medications.warnings: May increase risk of heart attack, stroke, and stomach/intestinal bleeding. Not for long-term use without medical supervision.
medications.sideEffects: Stomach upset, heartburn, dizziness, mild headache.
medications.contraindications: History of heart disease, stroke, stomach ulcers, kidney disease, asthma triggered by aspirin or NSAIDs.

medications.name: Diphenhydramine (Benadryl)
medications.dosageAdult: 25-50 mg every 4-6 hours as needed (max 300 mg/day)
medications.dosageChild: Not recommended for children under 6 without medical advice
medications.safetyNotes: Causes drowsiness. Do not drive or operate machinery.
medications.warnings: May cause significant drowsiness. Avoid alcohol.
medications.sideEffects: Drowsiness, dry mouth, dizziness, constipation, blurred vision.
medications.contraindications: Glaucoma, enlarged prostate, breathing problems, elderly individuals may be more sensitive.

medications.name: Loperamide (Imodium)
medications.dosageAdult: Initial 4 mg, then 2 mg after each loose stool (max 8 mg/day)
medications.dosageChild: Not recommended for children under 6 without medical advice
medications.safetyNotes: Not for diarrhea caused by bacteria or parasite infections. Seek medical help if diarrhea persists.
medications.warnings: Stop use and see doctor if diarrhea persists beyond 2 days or is accompanied by fever.
medications.sideEffects: Constipation, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, dry mouth.
medications.contraindications: Bloody diarrhea, severe colitis, bacterial enterocolitis.

medications.name: Loratadine (Claritin)
medications.dosageChild: Children 6-12: 10 mg once daily (consult healthcare provider for younger children)
medications.safetyNotes: Less drowsiness than older antihistamines. Generally safe for daytime use.
medications.warnings: May still cause drowsiness in some individuals.
medications.sideEffects: Headache, fatigue, dry mouth (less common than with other antihistamines).
medications.contraindications: Severe liver disease. Use with caution in elderly patients.

medications.name: Bismuth Subsalicylate (Pepto-Bismol)
medications.dosageAdult: 30 ml or 2 tablets every 30-60 minutes as needed (max 8 doses/24 hours)
medications.dosageChild: Not recommended for children under 12 without medical advice
medications.safetyNotes: May cause temporary darkening of tongue/stool. Contains aspirin-like ingredients.
medications.warnings: Do not use if allergic to aspirin. Not for use with anti-coagulants.
medications.contraindications: Aspirin allergy, bleeding disorders, anticoagulant use, children/teens with flu-like symptoms.

medications.name: Hydrocortisone Cream (0.5-1%)
medications.dosageAdult: Apply thin layer to affected area 1-4 times daily
medications.dosageChild: Use lower strength for children. Apply sparingly.
medications.safetyNotes: For external use only. Avoid eyes. Do not use on large areas for extended periods.
medications.warnings: Not for deep puncture wounds, animal bites or serious burns. Stop use if condition worsens.
medications.sideEffects: Skin irritation, redness, itching at application site.
medications.contraindications: Fungal skin infections, tuberculosis of the skin, most viral skin infections.

medications.name: Rehydration Solution (ORS)
medications.dosageChild: Children under 12: Based on weight - consult healthcare provider
medications.safetyNotes: Essential for preventing dehydration from diarrhea/vomiting. Can be homemade with salt, sugar and water.
medications.warnings: Not a substitute for medical care with severe dehydration.
medications.sideEffects: Generally none when used as directed.

medications.name: Calamine Lotion
medications.dosageAdult: Apply to affected area as needed
medications.safetyNotes: For external use only. Safe for most skin types.
medications.warnings: Avoid contact with eyes. Do not apply to broken skin or deep wounds.

medications.name: Antacid (Calcium Carbonate)
medications.dosageChild: Not recommended for children under 12 without medical advice
medications.safetyNotes: Fast-acting for acid indigestion. Contains calcium which may be beneficial.
medications.warnings: Prolonged use may affect absorption of some medications or cause kidney stones.
medications.sideEffects: Constipation, chalky taste, feeling of fullness.
medications.contraindications: Kidney disease, high calcium levels, certain heart conditions.

medications.name: Menthol Rub
medications.dosageAdult: Apply to affected area up to 3-4 times daily
medications.dosageChild: Not recommended for children under 2. Use sparingly for older children.
medications.safetyNotes: For external use only. Creates cooling sensation.
medications.warnings: Do not apply to wounds or damaged skin. Keep away from eyes and mucous membranes.
medications.contraindications: Sensitivity to menthol or other ingredients.

medications.name: Throat Lozenges
medications.dosageChild: Children over 6: Use as directed for adults
medications.safetyNotes: Do not exceed recommended dose. Dissolve slowly in mouth.
medications.warnings: Do not chew or swallow whole. Consult doctor if sore throat is severe or accompanied by fever.
medications.sideEffects: Rarely causes mouth irritation or allergic reactions.

medications.name: Saline Nasal Spray
medications.dosageChild: 1 spray per nostril as needed (safe for all ages)
medications.safetyNotes: Very safe, non-medicated salt water solution. Good for dry or congested nose.
medications.warnings: Use separate bottles for different people to prevent contamination.

medications.name: Antibiotic Ointment (Triple Antibiotic)
medications.dosageAdult: Apply small amount to affected area 1-3 times daily
medications.safetyNotes: For external use only. Clean wound before application.
medications.warnings: Do not use in deep puncture wounds or serious burns. Discontinue if rash develops.
medications.sideEffects: Skin irritation or allergic reaction in sensitive individuals.

medications.name: Activated Charcoal
medications.dosageAdult: 50-100 g as single dose (ONLY as directed by poison control center)
medications.dosageChild: 10-25 g (ONLY as directed by poison control center)
medications.safetyNotes: Not for routine use. Emergency product only. ALWAYS contact poison control before using.
medications.warnings: Not effective for all poisons. Do not give to unconscious person. Call emergency services.
medications.contraindications: Ingestion of corrosives, alcohol, or petroleum products.

disclaimer: This information is for educational purposes only and is not a substitute for professional medical advice. Always consult a healthcare provider for medical issues. These recommendations are for common over-the-counter medications and first aid. If symptoms are severe or persist, seek medical attention immediately.
